title: Masatomi Kimura
text:
, was an admiral in the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Biography.
Although born into the Kondō family of <a href="Shizuoka%2C%20Shizuoka">Shizuoka city</a> <a href="Shizuoka%20Prefecture">Shizuoka Prefecture</a>, Kimura was adopted by a family in <a href="Tottori%2C%20Tottori">Tottori city</a>, <a href="Tottori%20prefecture">Tottori prefecture</a> soon after birth, and considered Tottori his official residence. He was a graduate of the 41st class of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Naval%20Academy">Imperial Japanese Naval Academy</a>, but was a mediocre student, placing 107 out of 118 cadets.
Kimura served his cadet duty on the , making a cruise to <a href="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> and to the west coast of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. Commissioned as a <a href="midshipman">midshipman</a> on 9 December 1913, he transferred to on his return in 1914. After he was commissioned as an <a href="Ensign%20%28rank%29">ensign</a> on 1 December, he was assigned to the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> and . After completing required coursework in <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> warfare and <a href="naval%20artillery">naval artillery</a>, he was posted to the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean%20theater%20of%20World%20War%20II">South Pacific</a> in the closing stages of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. On his return to Japan in 1918, he was posted to the .
After his promotion to <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> in 1920, he commanded numerous <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a>s and <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweeper</a>s. In 1926, after he was promoted to <a href="lieutenant%20commander">lieutenant commander</a>, he was given command of the <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> . He subsequently captained the destroyers , , , , <a href="river%20gunboat">river gunboat</a>s , , destroyer , Destroyer Group 16, Destroyer Group 21, Destroyer Group 8, auxiliary <a href="seaplane%20tender">seaplane tender</a> "Kagu Maru", auxiliary oiler "Shiretoko", and cruisers and . He was promoted to <a href="commander">commander</a> in 1932 and to <a href="Captain%20%28naval%29">captain</a> in 1937.
Kimura was captain of "Suzuya" during the <a href="attack%20on%20Pearl%20Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a>. He later assisted in the rescue of the crew of the after that cruiser had been hit and sunk by American bombers during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Midway">Battle of Midway</a>. On 1 November 1942, Kimura was promoted to <a href="Rear%20Admiral">Rear Admiral</a>. He subsequently served in a number of staff positions, and was also commander of Desron3, with , , , , <a href="Japanese%20destroyer%20Yukikaze%20%281939%29">"Yukikaze"</a>, , , and . He was assigned to escort eight transports with 6000 soldiers of the <a href="IJA%2051st%20Division">IJA 51st Division</a> and 400 marines from <a href="Rabaul">Rabaul</a> to <a href="Lae">Lae</a>, <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a>. In the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Bismarck%20Sea">Battle of the Bismarck Sea</a> on 3–4 March 1943, <a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a> and <a href="RAAF">RAAF</a> bombers inflicted severe damage on the Japanese convoy, sinking all of the transports and four destroyers. Admiral Kimura was wounded by machine gun fire in the shoulder and stomach, and his flagship, "Shirayuki", was among the four destroyers sunk during the engagement. He, and most of his crew, were rescued by "Shikinami".
After recovering from his injuries, Kimura, with an augmented DesRon 1, was assigned to cover the withdrawal of Japanese troops from <a href="Kiska%20Island">Kiska Island</a> in the <a href="Aleutian%20Islands">Aleutians</a>. When poor weather threatened the withdrawal operations, Kimura disobeyed orders and remained on station until the last man was recovered. Still in command of DesRon 1, Kimura sortied from Pescadores, Formosa on 22 October 1944 to join Vice Admiral <a href="Kiyohide%20Shima">Kiyohide Shima</a>'s Second Striking Force in the battle of Surigao strait, transferring his flag from when she was disabled by a torpedo fired by Lieutenant (jg) Mike Kovar's PT-137. Afterward, in 1944, he was assigned to escort reinforcements to <a href="Leyte%20Island">Leyte Island</a> and <a href="Mindoro%20Island">Mindoro Island</a> in the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. In December 1944, Kimura led a raiding force of cruisers , , and the destroyers (flagship), , , , , and from Cam Ranh Bay to bombard the American beachhead in Mindoro in the Philippines on the night of 26 December 1944. On 1 April 1945, Kimura became commandant of the Anti-submarine Warfare School, and the Hofu Naval Communications School. He was promoted to <a href="Vice%20Admiral">Vice Admiral</a> on 1 November 1945, a few days before he entered the reserves on 10 November.
Kimura had a postwar career in the salt industry, and died of <a href="stomach%20cancer">stomach cancer</a> in 1960, aged 68.
